subject: Learning
title: Social Media and the Attention Span
description: A short lesson to help you apply Social Media and the Attention Span.

hook.text: Average time spent on a single piece of content has dropped from 12 seconds to 8 in a decade.

buildup.text: Social media platforms serve content in short, dopamine-optimized bursts designed for infinite scrolling.

discovery.text: Repeated exposure to rapid-fire content trains the brain to expect constant novelty and reward.

twist.text: When you sit down to read a book, your retrained brain finds it unbearably slow. It craves the scroll.

climax.text: Attention span isn't shrinking because people are lazier. It's adapting to the content environment.

punchline.text: Your attention adapted to survive the feed. Now it struggles with the page.

quiz.question: Why might social media reduce sustained attention span?
options: Rapid-fire content trains the brain to expect constant novelty and reward
Social media content is too complex for the brain
It only affects attention during social media use
